Integration vs. Merger

Purpose: clarify the difference between an integration/alliance and a merger in airline-industry reporting. This summary is educational and informational.

Quick Definitions

  • Integration / Alliance: Coordination of some operations/programs (e.g., reciprocal mileage, select schedule coordination, codeshares). Each company remains a separate corporate entity with its own certificate, workforce, and contracts.
  • Merger: Two companies combine into one. Over time this yields a single operating certificate, unified brand, and (after bargaining) joint labor agreements/seniority integration.

Typical Features

TopicIntegration / AllianceMerger
Corporate statusSeparate companiesSingle combined company
Operating certificateSeparate AOCs / DOT authorityMove toward a single AOC
Loyalty programsReciprocal earn/burn; status recognitionFull consolidation over time
Scheduling/slotsSelective coordination where permittedUnified network planning
Labor contractsRemain separate; no automatic changesJoint bargaining for a single agreement
Seniority listsUnaffectedIntegrated via applicable procedures
Regulatory reviewAlliance/transaction-specific + antitrust oversightFormal merger review/approvals

What Integration Is (and Isnt)

Integration steps improve interoperability but do not change who employs crews, alter union representation, or merge seniority. Those outcomes arise only from a corporate merger followed by the applicable statutory and bargaining processes.

Why the Distinction Matters

  1. Expectations: Integration can roll out quickly; mergers take longer and add legal steps.
  2. Labor implications: Existing CBAs/representation stay in force unless and until theres a merger and joint bargaining.
  3. Customer impact: Integration improves connectivity/loyalty now; mergers eventually unify product/brand.

Informational only; not legal advice.
